subject: Re: Test Coverage as a Metric

messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> So said Curt Sampson on 2003-02-06 --------------------
>
> >On Tue, 4 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:

> >Yes, Kent Beck indeed did say, "TDD followed religiously should
> >result in 100% statement coverage."

That's pretty religious. And not completely pragmatic. Should you
test drive toSting() methods that you want for nice test failure
reports? There are bits & piecs that very likely will slip through
untested. Some aren't a problem. You need a new exception... do you
test drive it or ask your IDE to make you a new exception with the
required constructors?

> To me, the bottom line with Test Coverage is that it is a "negative
> metric". Low test coverage is an indicator of failure; but high test
> coverage is not an indicator of success. Your code could be
> highly-covered by failing tests, after all. ;)

If this were the TDD list, I'd chastise you by saying that none of
them should fail once the code is written. :-) I would say "highly
covered by ineffective tests".

> That's why we need skilled testers: to fill in the gaps between
> Customer Tests (too high-level, often miss boundary conditions) and
> Programmer Tests (very low-level, often miss integration problems).

Agreed. There are methods and tools that can help programmers
maximize (or at least improve) the effectiveness of their tests.
Analyzing code coverage during the run of the highest level AllTests
suite is a first step. Running Jester regularly also helps find holes
in the test logic (note: that's very different than coverage).

Dave
